lessons.title: What is a Stock? slice of the Pie! üç∞
content: Imagine a big, yummy pie. That pie is a company (like a toy company or a video game company).
A 'stock' is like getting a tiny slice of that pie. When you own a stock, you own a small piece of the company! This makes you a 'shareholder'.

interactive_example.title: Let's Pretend!
interactive_example.scenario: Imagine we start a lemonade stand. We need $10 to buy lemons and sugar. We can sell 10 'shares' for $1 each. If you buy one share, you own 1/10th of our lemonade stand! If our stand makes money, your share becomes worth more.

external_links.name: Kids Finance - What is a Stock?

lessons.title: Why Sell Slices of the Pie?
content: Companies sell stocks to raise money. They can use this money to do cool things, like invent new products, build bigger factories, or hire more people.
It's like when we sold shares in our lemonade stand to get money for lemons. The company gets the money it needs to grow, and you get to own a part of it!

interactive_example.title: Game Company Goals
interactive_example.scenario: A game company wants to create a new video game, but they need $1,000,000. They can sell 100,000 shares for $10 each to raise the money. Now they can build their awesome new game!

lessons.title: The Price Rollercoaster üé¢
content: The price of a stock goes up and down. This is called 'volatility'.
If a lot of people want to buy a stock (high demand), the price goes up. If a lot of people want to sell it (low demand), the price goes down.
Good news about a company (like record sales) usually makes the price go up. Bad news (like a failed product) can make it go down.

interactive_example.title: News Flash!
interactive_example.scenario: In your game, you see a news event: 'RoboCorp Inc. just released a new super-fast robot!'. What do you think will happen to their stock price? It will probably go up because people are excited about the new robot!

lessons.title: Your Treasure Chest of Stocks üíé
content: A portfolio is just a collection of all the different stocks you own. Think of it like a treasure chest or a sticker book.
Instead of gold coins or stickers, your portfolio holds all your different shares from different companies.

interactive_example.title: Build Your Portfolio
interactive_example.scenario: Let's say you own 5 shares of 'GameFun' and 10 shares of 'CandyCorp'. Your portfolio contains both of these investments. In the game, your dashboard shows you your portfolio.

lessons.title: Don't Put All Your Eggs in One Basket! ü•ö
content: 'Diversification' is a fancy word for not putting all your money into just one stock. It's smarter to buy small amounts of many different stocks from different industries (like technology, food, and cars).
Why? If one company does poorly, you won't lose all your money because your other stocks might be doing great! This lowers your risk.

interactive_example.title: Smart Investing
interactive_example.scenario: You have $100. Is it smarter to put all $100 into one video game stock, or put $25 into a game stock, $25 into a food company, $25 into a car company, and $25 into a toy company? The second option is diversified and safer!
